nodes.text: Firms emerge as a contractual organizational form because team production creates costly metering problems that make market exchange inefficient for disciplining and rewarding jointly used inputs
Metering problem: efficient organization requires measuring input productivity and apportioning rewards, but measurement costs can be high so the organizational form affects productivity
Team production is production where multiple inputs produce a nonseparable joint output so individual marginal products are hard to observe from total output
When metering is costly under team production, individuals have incentives to shirk because private realizable costs of shirking are lower than the social costs, reducing total productivity
Specializing a monitor who is made a residual claimant (owner) reduces shirking by giving that monitor incentives to measure, direct, and alter inputs and contracts centrally
Markets can sometimes discipline teams through external competition and replacement of shirking members, but this is limited when detection costs are high or incentives for entrants are weak

Definition and conditions for classical firm: joint input production, multiple input owners, a central party common to all input contracts, unilateral renegotiation rights, residual claim, and right to sell that status
Metering costs act like a tax on work rewards leading to persistent, economically viable shirking instead of complete employer policing
Auxiliary assumption: costs of team production management rise if residual claim is widely shared; thus full profit sharing often increases monitor shirking and is less efficient for large teams
The residual claimant-monitor bundle of rights (observe input behavior, apportion rewards, alter membership, sell rights) defines ownership and explains why firms centralize control
Profit-sharing is viable primarily for small teams or professional/artistic work where monitoring is costly and reciprocal monitoring among few owners is effective

Different organizational forms follow from information and metering costs: corporations centralize residual rights and enable tradable shares; partnerships and cooperatives arise where self-monitoring is feasible; nonprofits/mutuals may have greater shirking because gains are not capitalized

Types of inputs owned versus hired: durable, resalable, and long-lived capital are more likely owner-invested by residual claimants; inputs whose user cost or abuse is observable in use are more likely owner-used than rented
Employee unions and worker committees function as specialized monitors when employees cannot costlessly observe or enforce contingent employer performance

The firm is a specialized private market institution that collects, collates, and sells information about heterogeneous inputs, enabling intrafirm competition and superior recombinations relative to decentralized search
